The term shebuat bittui means an oath by which we swear to do not not to do something which religion neither enjoins or forbids(As e.g. 'I swear that I will eat this loaf' or 'I swear that I will not eat this loaf'). We must fulfil an oath of this kind(see Pos Comm 94), and we are forbidden to violate it by the words, Ye shall not swear by My name falsely. The Gemara of Shebuoth says: 'What is a shebuat sheker (false oath)? Swearing that which is the reverse [of the truth. eg. swearing that one has eaten, when one has not]. This [definition the Sages] corrected to: Swearing and reversing: that is, swearing to do something and doing the reverse of that which one has sworn to do. The Gemara explains there - in the third chapter of Shebuoth - and also in Tractate Temurah, that shebuat sheker (a false oath) is the non-peformance of a shebuat bittui. The passage runs as follows: 'This false oath - what kind is meant?' - that is to say, as the context shows: What is meant by a false oath which entails no action? - 'Shall we say that what is meant is swearing not to eat and then eating? But in that case an actio is performed. We must, then, conclude that what is meant is swearing to eat and then not eating. But is there a penalty of whipping [for breach of a prohibition involving no action]? Surely we are told...', etc. The punishment for wilful breach of this prohibition is whipping; if one contravenes it unintentionally, he must offer a sacrifice of higher or lower value, as we have explained in dealing with Positive Commandment 72. This is based on the following passage in the third chapter of Shebuoth: 'This is a shbuat bittui, for which one is liable to whipping if he violates it wilfully, but if unwittingly must bring an offering of higher or lower value. The provisions of this Commandment are explained there. When I stated that the punishment for wilful transgression of this Commandment is whipping, you must know that I did not mean to imply that there is a sin which is punished by whipping even though not committed wilfully. Wherever you find me stating that a certain transgressio is punishable by whipping - whether in what procedes or in what follows - you must know that this applies solely to a sin committed wilfully, in the presence of witnesses, and in defiance of formal warning, as explained in Tractate Sanhedrin in coonection with the stipulations regarding witnesses and formal warning. One who sins unintentionally, or under duress, or through wrong information, is in no circumstances liable to whipping or extinction, and least of all to judicial execution. This applies to all the Commandments, and should be noted. In the case of some of the Commandments, we do indeed state that wilful violation is punishable by whipping or death, because the same sin committed unintentionally involves bringing an offering. The reason is that not all sins committed unintentionally involve bringing an offering. But wherever the penalty for a transgression is whipping, extinction, or judicial execution, the punishment is not incurred unless the sin was committed in the presence of witnesses, and in defiance of formal warning. It is known that the only object of formal warning is to make a distinction between ignorant and wilful violation. You should know this principle, and do not expect me to repeat it.

title: Swearing a shebuat shav
text: By this prohibition we are forbidden to swear a shebuat shav (a vain oath). It is contained in His words (exalted be He), Thou shall not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain(Ex. 20:7). It forbids us to swear that an existing object is not what it is in fact(as where one swears that a pillar of stone is of gold), or that something exists which is impossible(as where one swears that a camel may fly), or to swear to violate any of the Commandments of the Torah(as where one swears that he will not read the Shema). Similarly, if one swears to a self-evident fact, which no educated person would deny or question, as for example if one swears by the Lord that whatever is slaughtered will die, this too is a case of taking the name of the Lord in vain. In the words of Mishnah: 'What is a shebuat shav? Swearing that which is contrary to the facts known to man.' The punishment for wilful contravention of this prohibition is whipping; one who contravenes it unintentionally is exampt, like the rest of those guilty of transgressing the Negative Commandments, as we have explained. It is said in [Tractate] Shebuoth that for a shebuot shav the punishment is whipping if the offence is wilful, and there is no punishment if it is unwitting. The provisions of this Commandment are explained there.

title: Profaning the Name of God
text: By this prohibition we are forbidden to profane the Name. This is the opposite of the sanctification of the Name, which is enjoined on us by the ninth Positive Commandment, and which we have explained in that place. This prohibition is contained in His words(exalted be Help), Ye shall not profane My holy Name(Lev. 22:32). This sin embraces actions of three kinds, of which two are possible for anybody, and the third only for certain individuals. The first kind of action, which is possible for anybody, is this. Anyone who in a time of persecution is required to transgress one of the Commandments, whether his coercer has in mind to make him commit a lesser or a graver sin, or anyone who is required, even in a time when there is no persecution, to commit the sin of idolatry, or incest or bloodshed, must sacrifice his life and submit to death rather than transgress, as we have explained in connection with the ninth Positive Commandment. If he commits the sin and so escapes death, he profanes the Name and infringes this Negative Commandment; and if it happens in public, i.e. in the presence of ten Israelites, he profanes the Name publicly and sins against His words(exalted be He), Ye shall not profane My holy name, and his iniquity is very grievous; but he is not punished by whipping, because he acted under compulsion, and a court has no right to inflict punishment of whipping or death except on one who has sinned intentioanlly, of his own free will, before witnesses and in defiance of formal warning. As the Sifre says of one who gives a child to Molech: 'I will set my face against that man(Lev 20:5): the Sages say, that man, but not the man who sins under duress, or unintentionally, or though wrong information.' Thus it has been made clear to you that one who worships idols under duress is not liable to extinction, and still less to judicial execution, but he is guilty of profaning the Name. The second kind of action, also possible for anybody, is committing a transgression which, though not caused by lust or the desire for gain, shows indifference and laxity of behaviour. A man who acts in such a way is also guilty of profaning the Name and liable to whipping; wherefore Scipture says, Ye shall not swear by My name falsely, so that thou profane the name of thy God(Lev 19:12, See Neg Comm. 61), because such a one shows indifference, although he derives no material benefit[from his action]. The kind of action possible only for certain individuals is conduct by a man of known piety and righteousness which seems to the populace to be a transgression and to be unworthy of such a pious man, though it is in fact permitted. Such conduct also is profanation of the Name? [Rab says:] If for instance I take meat from the butcher and do not pay him at once(he would thus learn to treat his debts dishonestly by delaying payment and then omitting it altogether). R.Johanan says: In my case [it is a profanation if] I walk four cubits without [uttering words of] Torah or [wearing] phylacteries(Yoma 86a (Sonc.ed.p.427).'The greater a man is, the more scruplulous should he be in all things, doing more than the strict letter of the law requires'(Mishnah Torah, Mada, Hilchoth Yesode ha-Torah V,II). This prohibition is also found elsewhere in the words of Scripture: Neither shall thou profane the name of thy God: I am the Lord(Lev. 28:21). The provisions of this Commandment are explained in Pesahim and at the end of Yoma.

title: Testing His promises and warnings
text: By this prohibition we are forbidden to test His promises and threats(exalted be He), conveyed to us by His Prophets, by casting doubt upon them after we have learnt that he who uttered them is a true Prophet. This prohibition is contained in Hos words, Ye shall not try the Lord your God(Deut. 6:16). NOTE according to Saadia Gaon, this Commandment also prohibits testing God's attributes with a view to establishing His almighty and unlimited powers, as Israel did in the desert: And they tries God in their heart...Behold, He smote the rock...can He give bread also? Also will He provide flesh for His people?(Ps. LXXVII,18-20;quoted in KImchi's commentary on Judges VI,39). Finally, the Commendment also prohibits exposing oneself to mortal danger and expecting the Almighty to perform a miracle to save him(1 Sam 16:2, Kimchi).

title: Breaking down houses of worship
text: By this prohibition we are forbidden to break down houses of worship of the Lord, or to destroy books of prophecy, or to erase the Sacred Names, and the like. This prohibition is contained in His words, Ye shall not do so unto the Lord your God(Deut 12:4). Having commanded us to destroy the idols, to erase their names, and to demolish completely their temples and altars(Deut 12:2-3; see Pos Comm 185), He adds the prohibition, Ye shall not do so unto the Lord your God. The punishment for contravention of this prohibition in any particular - such as pulling down any part of the Sanctuary, or the Altar, or the like, or erasing any if the Names of the Lord - is whipping. The Gemara, after explaining at the end of Makkoth that burning firewood belonging to the Sanctuary is punishable by whipping, adds: 'This prohibition is to be found in the words: Ye shall burn their Asherim with fire...Ye shall not do so unto the Lord your God(Deut 12:3-4;Mak.22a(Sonc.ed.p.150).' Similarly, after explaining there that the penalty for erasing the Divine Name is whipping, it goes on: 'The prohibition is to be found in the words, Ye shall destroy their name out of that place. Ye shall not do so unto the Lord.' The provisions of this Commandment are explained in the fourth chapter of Shebuoth. NOTE according to the 'Mishneh Torah', the law against destroying sacred writings applies only to Scripture written by an Israelite, conscious of their sacred character. But if an Israelite who is an infidel writes a Scroll of the Torah, it is burnt with all the Names of God contained therein. The reason is that he does not believe in the sanctity of the Divine Name, and did not write the Scroll as a religious duty, but regarded it as being like any other writing.

title: Leaving the body of a criminal hanging overnight after execution
text: By this prohibition we are forbidden to leave the body [of a criminal] after execution hanging overnight on the tree, so that the sight of it may not give rise to sacrilegious thoughts. Hanging is practised by us only in the case of the blasphemer and the idol-worhipper, of whom also it is said: He blasphemeth the Lord(Num 15:30. Hence, hanging, which is the punishment laid down for blasphemy(Deut 21:23), is prescribed also for idol-worship, which is a form of blasphemy. This prohibition is contained in His words(exalted be He), His body shall not remain all night upon the tree(Deut 21:23), on which the Sifre says: 'His body shall not remain all night is a Negative Commandment.' The provisions of this Commandment are explained in the sixth chapter of Sanhedrin.

title: Interrupting the watch over the Sanctuary
text: By this prohibition we are forbidden to interrupt the watch over the Sanctuary, which must be continuously patrolled throughout the night. This prohibition is contained in His words, Ye shall keep (ush'martem) the charge of the holy things(Num 18:5. This is the general rule: wherever Scripture says 'Beware' or 'Take heed' (hisshamer), or 'Lest' (pen) or 'Do not'(al), the verse contains a Negative Commandment(Neg Comm 231). We have already explained, in dealing with Positive Commandment 22, that to keep guard over and patrol the Sanctuary is a Positive Commandment; and here we will show that to neglect this is to infringe a Negative Commandment. [This appears from] the words of the Mechilta: 'And they shall keep the charge of the tent of meeting(Num 18:4): this only [makes the observance of this charge] a Positive Commandment: but whence can we infer that [its neglect] is [a breach of] a Negative Commandment? From the words in Scripture: Ye shall keep the charge of the holy things.' The provisions of this Commandment are explained at the beginning of Tamid and Middoth.

title: The High Priest entering the Sanctuary at any but the prescribed time
text: By this prohibition the High Priest is forbidden to enter the Sanctuary at any and all times, because of the respect due to the Sanctuary and the awe one should have of the Divine Presence. This prohibition this contained His words(exalted be He), [Speak unto Aaron thy brother,] that he come not at all times into the holy place [within the veil, before the ark-cover which is upon the ark; that he die not].(Lev 16:2). This prohibition includes a number of restrictions. The High Priest is forbidden to enter the Holy of Holies even on the Day of Atonement except at the times presecribed for service(see Pso Comm 49); and all priests are forbidden to enter the Sanctuary at any time during the year except at the time of service. Briefly, it is forbidden for any priest to enter the place which he is allowed to enter - that is, the Inner Sanctum in the case of the High Priest, and the outer Sanctuary in the case of an ordinary priests - except during the time of service. One who violates this prohibition by entering outside the time of service is liable to death [by the hand of Heaven] if he eneters the Holy of Holies, and to whipping if he enters the Sanctuary. The Sifre says: 'That he come not at all times refers to the Day of Atonement; into the holy place covers also the rest of the year; within the veil makes the prohibition apply to to the whole of the Sanctuary. It might be thought that entering any part of the Sanctuary is punishable by death: Scripture therefore says, Before the ark-cover which is upon the ark; that he die not. What does this mean? Entering[the inner part of the Sanctuary, which is] before the ark-cover [that is, the Holy of Holies] is punishable by death, and entering the rest of the Sanctuary by whipping(Lev 16:2, Sifre.Men.27b). The gemara of Menahoth says explicitly: 'For entering the Sanctuary [outside the time of service] one is liable to whipping.'

title: A Priest with blemish entering any part of the Sanctuary
text: By this prohibition a priest with a blemish is forbidden to enter any part of the Sanctuary, that is, [the place where] the Altar [stands], or the space between the Porch and the Altar, or the Porch itself, or the Sanctuary proper. This prohibition is contained in His words(exalted be He), Only he shall not go un unto the veil, nor come nigh the altar(Lev. 21:23). It is explained at the beginning of Tohoroth that one who has a blemish, or whose hair is unloosed(See Neg Comm 163), is forbidden to enter the space between the Porch and the Altar, or any part of the Sanctuary. The Sifre also explains that these two prohibitions, Only he shall not go in unto the veil, and Nor shall he come nigh unto the altar, would not suffice one without the other, and both are necessary to make the law on this matter complete: the law, namely, that defines the place into which entry is forbidden [to those in question](Lev.21:23,Sifre). One who wilfully goes in beyond the Altar is liable to whipping, even if he does not enter for the purpose of ministering.
